segment.source: 4768(S, F) A Kerberos authentication ticket (TGT) was requested.
segment.target: 4768(S, F) A Kerberos authentication ticket (TGT) was requested.

segment.source: Describes security event 4768(S, F) A Kerberos authentication ticket (TGT) was requested.
segment.target: Describes security event 4768(S, F) A Kerberos authentication ticket (TGT) was requested.

segment.source: 4768(S, F): A Kerberos authentication ticket (TGT) was requested.
segment.target: 4768(S, F): A Kerberos authentication ticket (TGT) was requested.

segment.source: This event generates every time Key Distribution Center issues a Kerberos Ticket Granting Ticket (TGT).
segment.target: This event generates every time Key Distribution Center issues a Kerberos Ticket Granting Ticket (TGT).

segment.source: This event generates only on domain controllers.
segment.target: This event generates only on domain controllers.

segment.source: If TGT issue fails then you will see Failure event with Result Code field not equal to “0x0”.
segment.target: If TGT issue fails then you will see Failure event with Result Code field not equal to “0x0”.

segment.source: This event doesn't generate for Result Codes: 0x10, 0x17 and 0x18.
segment.target: This event doesn't generate for Result Codes: 0x10, 0x17 and 0x18.

segment.source: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.
segment.target: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.

segment.source: Required Server Roles: Active Directory domain controller.
segment.target: Required Server Roles: Active Directory domain controller.

segment.source: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of account, for which (TGT) ticket was requested.
segment.target: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of account, for which (TGT) ticket was requested.

segment.source: Computer account name ends with character.
segment.target: Computer account name ends with character.

segment.source: Supplied Realm Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the Kerberos Realm that Account Name belongs to.
segment.target: Supplied Realm Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the Kerberos Realm that Account Name belongs to.

segment.source: This can appear in a variety of formats, including the following:
segment.target: This can appear in a variety of formats, including the following:

segment.source: Note A Kerberos Realm is a set of managed nodes that share the same Kerberos database.
segment.target: Note A Kerberos Realm is a set of managed nodes that share the same Kerberos database.

segment.source: The Kerberos database resides on the Kerberos master computer system, which should be kept in a physically secure room.
segment.target: The Kerberos database resides on the Kerberos master computer system, which should be kept in a physically secure room.

segment.source: Active Directory domain is the example of Kerberos Realm in the Microsoft Windows Active Directory world.
segment.target: Active Directory domain is the example of Kerberos Realm in the Microsoft Windows Active Directory world.

segment.source: User ID Type = SID: SID of account for which (TGT) ticket was requested.
segment.target: User ID Type = SID: SID of account for which (TGT) ticket was requested.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: NULL SID – this value shows in 4768 Failure events.
segment.target: NULL SID – this value shows in 4768 Failure events.

segment.source: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).
segment.target: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).

segment.source: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.
segment.target: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.

segment.source: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.
segment.target: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.

segment.source: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.
segment.target: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.

segment.source: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.
segment.target: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.

segment.source: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.
segment.target: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.

segment.source: Service Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the service in the Kerberos Realm to which TGT request was sent.
segment.target: Service Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the service in the Kerberos Realm to which TGT request was sent.

segment.source: Typically has value “krbtgt” for TGT requests, which means Ticket Granting Ticket issuing service.
segment.target: Typically has value “krbtgt” for TGT requests, which means Ticket Granting Ticket issuing service.

segment.source: For Failure events Service Name typically has the following format: krbtgt/REALMNAME.
segment.target: For Failure events Service Name typically has the following format: krbtgt/REALMNAME.

segment.source: Service ID Type = SID: SID of the service account in the Kerberos Realm to which TGT request was sent.
segment.target: Service ID Type = SID: SID of the service account in the Kerberos Realm to which TGT request was sent.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Domain controllers have a specific service account (krbtgt) that is used by the Key Distribution Center (KDC) service to issue Kerberos tickets.
segment.target: Domain controllers have a specific service account (krbtgt) that is used by the Key Distribution Center (KDC) service to issue Kerberos tickets.

segment.source: It has a built-in, pre-defined SID: S-1-5-21-DOMAINIDENTIFIER-502.
segment.target: It has a built-in, pre-defined SID: S-1-5-21-DOMAINIDENTIFIER-502.

segment.source: NULL SID – this value shows in 4768 Failure events.
segment.target: NULL SID – this value shows in 4768 Failure events.

segment.source: Client Address Type = UnicodeString: IP address of the computer from which the TGT request was received.
segment.target: Client Address Type = UnicodeString: IP address of the computer from which the TGT request was received.

segment.source: Formats vary, and include the following:
segment.target: Formats vary, and include the following:

segment.source: Client Port Type = UnicodeString: source port number of client network connection (TGT request connection).
segment.target: Client Port Type = UnicodeString: source port number of client network connection (TGT request connection).

segment.source: Ticket Options Type = HexInt32: this is a set of different ticket flags in hexadecimal format.
segment.target: Ticket Options Type = HexInt32: this is a set of different ticket flags in hexadecimal format.

segment.source: Using MSB 0 bit numbering we have bit 1, 8, 15 and 27 set = Forwardable, Renewable, Canonicalize, Renewable-ok.
segment.target: Using MSB 0 bit numbering we have bit 1, 8, 15 and 27 set = Forwardable, Renewable, Canonicalize, Renewable-ok.

segment.source: Note In the table below “MSB 0” bit numbering is used, because RFC documents use this style.
segment.target: Note In the table below “MSB 0” bit numbering is used, because RFC documents use this style.

segment.source: In “MSB 0” style bit numbering begins from left.
segment.target: In “MSB 0” style bit numbering begins from left.

segment.source: Tells the ticket-granting service that it can issue a new TGT—based on the presented TGT—with a different network address based on the presented TGT.
segment.target: Tells the ticket-granting service that it can issue a new TGT—based on the presented TGT—with a different network address based on the presented TGT.

segment.source: Indicates either that a TGT has been forwarded or that a ticket was issued from a forwarded TGT.
segment.target: Indicates either that a TGT has been forwarded or that a ticket was issued from a forwarded TGT.

segment.source: Tells the ticket-granting service that it can issue tickets with a network address that differs from the one in the TGT.
segment.target: Tells the ticket-granting service that it can issue tickets with a network address that differs from the one in the TGT.

segment.source: Indicates that the network address in the ticket is different from the one in the TGT used to obtain the ticket.
segment.target: Indicates that the network address in the ticket is different from the one in the TGT used to obtain the ticket.

segment.source: Postdated tickets SHOULD NOT be supported in KILE (Microsoft Kerberos Protocol Extension).
segment.target: Postdated tickets SHOULD NOT be supported in KILE (Microsoft Kerberos Protocol Extension).

segment.source: Postdated tickets SHOULD NOT be supported in KILE (Microsoft Kerberos Protocol Extension).
segment.target: Postdated tickets SHOULD NOT be supported in KILE (Microsoft Kerberos Protocol Extension).

segment.source: This flag indicates that a ticket is invalid, and it must be validated by the KDC before use.
segment.target: This flag indicates that a ticket is invalid, and it must be validated by the KDC before use.

segment.source: Application servers must reject tickets which have this flag set.
segment.target: Application servers must reject tickets which have this flag set.

segment.source: Used in combination with the End Time and Renew Till fields to cause tickets with long life spans to be renewed at the KDC periodically.
segment.target: Used in combination with the End Time and Renew Till fields to cause tickets with long life spans to be renewed at the KDC periodically.

segment.source: Indicates that a ticket was issued using the authentication service (AS) exchange and not issued based on a TGT.
segment.target: Indicates that a ticket was issued using the authentication service (AS) exchange and not issued based on a TGT.

segment.source: Indicates that the client was authenticated by the KDC before a ticket was issued.
segment.target: Indicates that the client was authenticated by the KDC before a ticket was issued.

segment.source: This flag usually indicates the presence of an authenticator in the ticket.
segment.target: This flag usually indicates the presence of an authenticator in the ticket.

segment.source: It can also flag the presence of credentials taken from a smart card logon.
segment.target: It can also flag the presence of credentials taken from a smart card logon.

segment.source: This flag was originally intended to indicate that hardware-supported authentication was used during pre-authentication.
segment.target: This flag was originally intended to indicate that hardware-supported authentication was used during pre-authentication.

segment.source: This flag is no longer recommended in the Kerberos V5 protocol.
segment.target: This flag is no longer recommended in the Kerberos V5 protocol.

segment.source: KDCs MUST NOT issue a ticket with this flag set.
segment.target: KDCs MUST NOT issue a ticket with this flag set.

segment.source: KDCs SHOULD NOT preserve this flag if it is set by another KDC.
segment.target: KDCs SHOULD NOT preserve this flag if it is set by another KDC.

segment.source: KILE MUST NOT check for transited domains on servers or a KDC.
segment.target: KILE MUST NOT check for transited domains on servers or a KDC.

segment.source: Application servers MUST ignore the TRANSITED-POLICY-CHECKED flag.
segment.target: Application servers MUST ignore the TRANSITED-POLICY-CHECKED flag.

segment.source: The KDC MUST set the OK-AS-DELEGATE flag if the service account is trusted for delegation.
segment.target: The KDC MUST set the OK-AS-DELEGATE flag if the service account is trusted for delegation.

segment.source: In order to request referrals the Kerberos client MUST explicitly request the "canonicalize" KDC option for the AS-REQ or TGS-REQ.
segment.target: In order to request referrals the Kerberos client MUST explicitly request the "canonicalize" KDC option for the AS-REQ or TGS-REQ.

segment.source: By default the KDC will check the transited field of a TGT against the policy of the local realm before it will issue derivative tickets based on the TGT.
segment.target: By default the KDC will check the transited field of a TGT against the policy of the local realm before it will issue derivative tickets based on the TGT.

segment.source: If this flag is set in the request, checking of the transited field is disabled.
segment.target: If this flag is set in the request, checking of the transited field is disabled.

segment.source: Tickets issued without the performance of this check will be noted by the reset (0) value of the TRANSITED-POLICY-CHECKED flag, indicating to the application server that the transited field must be checked locally.
segment.target: Tickets issued without the performance of this check will be noted by the reset (0) value of the TRANSITED-POLICY-CHECKED flag, indicating to the application server that the transited field must be checked locally.

segment.source: KDCs are encouraged but not required to honor
segment.target: KDCs are encouraged but not required to honor

segment.source: Should not be in use, because Transited-policy-checked flag is not supported by KILE.
segment.target: Should not be in use, because Transited-policy-checked flag is not supported by KILE.

segment.source: The RENEWABLE-OK option indicates that a renewable ticket will be acceptable if a ticket with the requested life cannot otherwise be provided, in which case a renewable ticket may be issued with a renew-till equal to the requested end time.
segment.target: The RENEWABLE-OK option indicates that a renewable ticket will be acceptable if a ticket with the requested life cannot otherwise be provided, in which case a renewable ticket may be issued with a renew-till equal to the requested end time.

segment.source: The value of the renew-till field may still be limited by local limits, or limits selected by the individual principal or server.
segment.target: The value of the renew-till field may still be limited by local limits, or limits selected by the individual principal or server.

segment.source: The RENEW option indicates that the present request is for a renewal.
segment.target: The RENEW option indicates that the present request is for a renewal.

segment.source: The ticket provided is encrypted in the secret key for the server on which it is valid.
segment.target: The ticket provided is encrypted in the secret key for the server on which it is valid.

segment.source: This option will only be honored if the ticket to be renewed has its RENEWABLE flag set and if the time in it’s renew-till field has not passed.
segment.target: This option will only be honored if the ticket to be renewed has its RENEWABLE flag set and if the time in it’s renew-till field has not passed.

segment.source: The ticket to be renewed is passed in the padata field as part of the authentication header.
segment.target: The ticket to be renewed is passed in the padata field as part of the authentication header.

segment.source: This option is used only by the ticket-granting service.
segment.target: This option is used only by the ticket-granting service.

segment.source: The VALIDATE option indicates that the request is to validate a postdated ticket.
segment.target: The VALIDATE option indicates that the request is to validate a postdated ticket.

segment.source: Should not be in use, because postdated tickets are not supported by KILE.
segment.target: Should not be in use, because postdated tickets are not supported by KILE.

segment.source:
Note
KILE (Microsoft Kerberos Protocol Extension) – Kerberos protocol extensions used in Microsoft operating systems.
segment.target:
Note
KILE (Microsoft Kerberos Protocol Extension) – Kerberos protocol extensions used in Microsoft operating systems.

segment.source: These extensions provide additional capability for authorization information including group memberships, interactive logon information, and integrity levels.
segment.target: These extensions provide additional capability for authorization information including group memberships, interactive logon information, and integrity levels.

segment.source: Result Code Type = HexInt32: hexadecimal result code of TGT issue operation.
segment.target: Result Code Type = HexInt32: hexadecimal result code of TGT issue operation.

segment.source: contains the list of the most common error codes for this event.
segment.target: contains the list of the most common error codes for this event.

segment.source: Client's entry in KDC database has expired
segment.target: Client's entry in KDC database has expired

segment.source: Server's entry in KDC database has expired
segment.target: Server's entry in KDC database has expired

segment.source: Requested Kerberos version number not supported
segment.target: Requested Kerberos version number not supported

segment.source: Client's key encrypted in old master key
segment.target: Client's key encrypted in old master key

segment.source: Server's key encrypted in old master key
segment.target: Server's key encrypted in old master key

segment.source: Client not found in Kerberos database
segment.target: Client not found in Kerberos database

segment.source: Server not found in Kerberos database
segment.target: Server not found in Kerberos database

segment.source: This error can occur if the domain controller cannot find the server’s name in Active Directory.
segment.target: This error can occur if the domain controller cannot find the server’s name in Active Directory.

segment.source: This error is similar to KDCERRCPRINCIPALUNKNOWN except that it occurs when the server name cannot be found.
segment.target: This error is similar to KDCERRCPRINCIPALUNKNOWN except that it occurs when the server name cannot be found.

segment.source: Multiple principal entries in KDC database
segment.target: Multiple principal entries in KDC database

segment.source: This error occurs if duplicate principal names exist.
segment.target: This error occurs if duplicate principal names exist.

segment.source: Unique principal names are crucial for ensuring mutual authentication.
segment.target: Unique principal names are crucial for ensuring mutual authentication.

segment.source: Thus, duplicate principal names are strictly forbidden, even across multiple realms.
segment.target: Thus, duplicate principal names are strictly forbidden, even across multiple realms.

segment.source: Without unique principal names, the client has no way of ensuring that the server it is communicating with is the correct one.
segment.target: Without unique principal names, the client has no way of ensuring that the server it is communicating with is the correct one.

segment.source: The client or server has a null key (master key)
segment.target: The client or server has a null key (master key)

segment.source: No master key was found for client or server.
segment.target: No master key was found for client or server.

segment.source: Usually it means that administrator should reset the password on the account.
segment.target: Usually it means that administrator should reset the password on the account.

segment.source: This error can occur if a client requests postdating of a Kerberos ticket.
segment.target: This error can occur if a client requests postdating of a Kerberos ticket.

segment.source: Postdating is the act of requesting that a ticket’s start time be set into the future.
segment.target: Postdating is the act of requesting that a ticket’s start time be set into the future.

segment.source: It also can occur if there is a time difference between the client and the KDC.
segment.target: It also can occur if there is a time difference between the client and the KDC.

segment.source: Requested start time is later than end time
segment.target: Requested start time is later than end time

segment.source: There is a time difference between the KDC and the client.
segment.target: There is a time difference between the KDC and the client.

segment.source: Requested start time is later than end time
segment.target: Requested start time is later than end time

segment.source: This error is usually the result of logon restrictions in place on a user’s account.
segment.target: This error is usually the result of logon restrictions in place on a user’s account.

segment.source: For example workstation restriction, smart card authentication requirement or logon time restriction.
segment.target: For example workstation restriction, smart card authentication requirement or logon time restriction.

segment.source: The SPN to which the client is attempting to delegate credentials is not in its Allowed-to-delegate-to list
segment.target: The SPN to which the client is attempting to delegate credentials is not in its Allowed-to-delegate-to list

segment.source: KDC has no support for encryption type
segment.target: KDC has no support for encryption type

segment.source: In general, this error occurs when the KDC or a client receives a packet that it cannot decrypt.
segment.target: In general, this error occurs when the KDC or a client receives a packet that it cannot decrypt.

segment.source: KDC has no support for checksum type
segment.target: KDC has no support for checksum type

segment.source: The KDC, server, or client receives a packet for which it does not have a key of the appropriate encryption type.
segment.target: The KDC, server, or client receives a packet for which it does not have a key of the appropriate encryption type.

segment.source: The result is that the computer is unable to decrypt the ticket.
segment.target: The result is that the computer is unable to decrypt the ticket.

segment.source: KDC has no support for PADATA type (pre-authentication data)
segment.target: KDC has no support for PADATA type (pre-authentication data)

segment.source: Smart card logon is being attempted and the proper certificate cannot be located.
segment.target: Smart card logon is being attempted and the proper certificate cannot be located.

segment.source: This can happen because the wrong certification authority (CA) is being queried or the proper CA cannot be contacted.
segment.target: This can happen because the wrong certification authority (CA) is being queried or the proper CA cannot be contacted.

segment.source: It can also happen when a domain controller doesn’t have a certificate installed for smart cards (Domain Controller or Domain Controller Authentication templates).
segment.target: It can also happen when a domain controller doesn’t have a certificate installed for smart cards (Domain Controller or Domain Controller Authentication templates).

segment.source: This error code cannot occur in event “4768.
segment.target: This error code cannot occur in event “4768.

segment.source: A Kerberos authentication ticket (TGT) was requested”.
segment.target: A Kerberos authentication ticket (TGT) was requested”.

segment.source: KDC has no support for transited type
segment.target: KDC has no support for transited type

segment.source: This might be because of an explicit disabling or because of other restrictions in place on the account.
segment.target: This might be because of an explicit disabling or because of other restrictions in place on the account.

segment.source: For example: account disabled, expired, or locked out.
segment.target: For example: account disabled, expired, or locked out.

segment.source: Credentials for server have been revoked
segment.target: Credentials for server have been revoked

segment.source: Since the remote KDC may change its PKCROSS key while there are PKCROSS tickets still active, it SHOULD cache the old PKCROSS keys until the last issued PKCROSS ticket expires.
segment.target: Since the remote KDC may change its PKCROSS key while there are PKCROSS tickets still active, it SHOULD cache the old PKCROSS keys until the last issued PKCROSS ticket expires.

segment.source: Otherwise, the remote KDC will respond to a client with a KRB-ERROR message of type KDCERRTGTREVOKED.
segment.target: Otherwise, the remote KDC will respond to a client with a KRB-ERROR message of type KDCERRTGTREVOKED.

segment.source: Client not yet valid—try again later
segment.target: Client not yet valid—try again later

segment.source: Server not yet valid—try again later
segment.target: Server not yet valid—try again later

segment.source: Password has expired—change password to reset
segment.target: Password has expired—change password to reset

segment.source: This error code cannot occur in event “4768.
segment.target: This error code cannot occur in event “4768.

segment.source: A Kerberos authentication ticket (TGT) was requested”.
segment.target: A Kerberos authentication ticket (TGT) was requested”.

segment.source: This error code cannot occur in event “4768.
segment.target: This error code cannot occur in event “4768.

segment.source: A Kerberos authentication ticket (TGT) was requested”.
segment.target: A Kerberos authentication ticket (TGT) was requested”.

segment.source: This error often occurs in UNIX interoperability scenarios.
segment.target: This error often occurs in UNIX interoperability scenarios.

segment.source: MIT-Kerberos clients do not request pre-authentication when they send a KRBASREQ message.
segment.target: MIT-Kerberos clients do not request pre-authentication when they send a KRBASREQ message.

segment.source: If pre-authentication is required (the default), Windows systems will send this error.
segment.target: If pre-authentication is required (the default), Windows systems will send this error.

segment.source: Most MIT-Kerberos clients will respond to this error by giving the pre-authentication, in which case the error can be ignored, but some clients might not respond in this way.
segment.target: Most MIT-Kerberos clients will respond to this error by giving the pre-authentication, in which case the error can be ignored, but some clients might not respond in this way.

segment.source: KDC does not know about the requested server
segment.target: KDC does not know about the requested server

segment.source: Integrity check on decrypted field failed
segment.target: Integrity check on decrypted field failed

segment.source: The authenticator was encrypted with something other than the session key.
segment.target: The authenticator was encrypted with something other than the session key.

segment.source: The result is that the client cannot decrypt the resulting message.
segment.target: The result is that the client cannot decrypt the resulting message.

segment.source: The modification of the message could be the result of an attack or it could be because of network noise.
segment.target: The modification of the message could be the result of an attack or it could be because of network noise.

segment.source: The smaller the value for the “Maximum lifetime for user ticket” Kerberos policy setting, the more likely it is that this error will occur.
segment.target: The smaller the value for the “Maximum lifetime for user ticket” Kerberos policy setting, the more likely it is that this error will occur.

segment.source: Because ticket renewal is automatic, you should not have to do anything if you get this message.
segment.target: Because ticket renewal is automatic, you should not have to do anything if you get this message.

segment.source: The ticket is not yet valid
segment.target: The ticket is not yet valid

segment.source: The ticket presented to the server is not yet valid (in relationship to the server time).
segment.target: The ticket presented to the server is not yet valid (in relationship to the server time).

segment.source: The most probable cause is that the clocks on the KDC and the client are not synchronized.
segment.target: The most probable cause is that the clocks on the KDC and the client are not synchronized.

segment.source: If cross-realm Kerberos authentication is being attempted, then you should verify time synchronization between the KDC in the target realm and the KDC in the client realm, as well.
segment.target: If cross-realm Kerberos authentication is being attempted, then you should verify time synchronization between the KDC in the target realm and the KDC in the client realm, as well.

segment.source: This error indicates that a specific authenticator showed up twice — the KDC has detected that this session ticket duplicates one that it has already received.
segment.target: This error indicates that a specific authenticator showed up twice — the KDC has detected that this session ticket duplicates one that it has already received.

segment.source: The ticket is not for us
segment.target: The ticket is not for us

segment.source: The server has received a ticket that was meant for a different realm.
segment.target: The server has received a ticket that was meant for a different realm.

segment.source: The ticket and authenticator do not match
segment.target: The ticket and authenticator do not match

segment.source: The KRBTGSREQ is being sent to the wrong KDC.
segment.target: The KRBTGSREQ is being sent to the wrong KDC.

segment.source: There is an account mismatch during protocol transition.
segment.target: There is an account mismatch during protocol transition.

segment.source: The clock skew is too great
segment.target: The clock skew is too great

segment.source: This error is logged if a client computer sends a timestamp whose value differs from that of the server’s timestamp by more than the number of minutes found in the “Maximum tolerance for computer clock synchronization” setting in Kerberos policy.
segment.target: This error is logged if a client computer sends a timestamp whose value differs from that of the server’s timestamp by more than the number of minutes found in the “Maximum tolerance for computer clock synchronization” setting in Kerberos policy.

segment.source: Network address in network layer header doesn't match address inside ticket
segment.target: Network address in network layer header doesn't match address inside ticket

segment.source: Session tickets MAY include the addresses from which they are valid.
segment.target: Session tickets MAY include the addresses from which they are valid.

segment.source: This error can occur if the address of the computer sending the ticket is different from the valid address in the ticket.
segment.target: This error can occur if the address of the computer sending the ticket is different from the valid address in the ticket.

segment.source: A possible cause of this could be an Internet Protocol (IP) address change.
segment.target: A possible cause of this could be an Internet Protocol (IP) address change.

segment.source: Another possible cause is when a ticket is passed through a proxy server or NAT.
segment.target: Another possible cause is when a ticket is passed through a proxy server or NAT.

segment.source: The client is unaware of the address scheme used by the proxy server, so unless the program caused the client to request a proxy server ticket with the proxy server's source address, the ticket could be invalid.
segment.target: The client is unaware of the address scheme used by the proxy server, so unless the program caused the client to request a proxy server ticket with the proxy server's source address, the ticket could be invalid.

segment.source: When an application receives a KRBSAFE message, it verifies it.
segment.target: When an application receives a KRBSAFE message, it verifies it.

segment.source: If any error occurs, an error code is reported for use by the application.
segment.target: If any error occurs, an error code is reported for use by the application.

segment.source: The message is first checked by verifying that the protocol version and type fields match the current version and KRBSAFE, respectively.
segment.target: The message is first checked by verifying that the protocol version and type fields match the current version and KRBSAFE, respectively.

segment.source: This message is generated when target server finds that message format is wrong.
segment.target: This message is generated when target server finds that message format is wrong.

segment.source: This applies to KRBAPREQ, KRBSAFE, KRBPRIV and KRBCRED messages.
segment.target: This applies to KRBAPREQ, KRBSAFE, KRBPRIV and KRBCRED messages.

segment.source: This error also generated if use of UDP protocol is being attempted with User-to-User authentication.
segment.target: This error also generated if use of UDP protocol is being attempted with User-to-User authentication.

segment.source: Message stream modified and checksum didn't match
segment.target: Message stream modified and checksum didn't match

segment.source: The authentication data was encrypted with the wrong key for the intended server.
segment.target: The authentication data was encrypted with the wrong key for the intended server.

segment.source: The authentication data was modified in transit by a hardware or software error, or by an attacker.
segment.target: The authentication data was modified in transit by a hardware or software error, or by an attacker.

segment.source: The client sent the authentication data to the wrong server because incorrect DNS data caused the client to send the request to the wrong server.
segment.target: The client sent the authentication data to the wrong server because incorrect DNS data caused the client to send the request to the wrong server.

segment.source: The client sent the authentication data to the wrong server because DNS data was out-of-date on the client.
segment.target: The client sent the authentication data to the wrong server because DNS data was out-of-date on the client.

segment.source: This event generates for KRBSAFE and KRBPRIV messages if an incorrect sequence number is included, or if a sequence number is expected but not present.
segment.target: This event generates for KRBSAFE and KRBPRIV messages if an incorrect sequence number is included, or if a sequence number is expected but not present.

segment.source: Specified version of key is not available
segment.target: Specified version of key is not available

segment.source: This error might be generated on server side during receipt of invalid KRBAPREQ message.
segment.target: This error might be generated on server side during receipt of invalid KRBAPREQ message.

segment.source: If the key version indicated by the Ticket in the KRBAPREQ is not one the server can use (e.g., it indicates an old key, and the server no longer possesses a copy of the old key), the KRBAPERRBADKEYVER error is returned.
segment.target: If the key version indicated by the Ticket in the KRBAPREQ is not one the server can use (e.g., it indicates an old key, and the server no longer possesses a copy of the old key), the KRBAPERRBADKEYVER error is returned.

segment.source: This error might be generated on server side during receipt of invalid KRBAPREQ message.
segment.target: This error might be generated on server side during receipt of invalid KRBAPREQ message.

segment.source: Because it is possible for the server to be registered in multiple realms, with different keys in each, the realm field in the unencrypted portion of the ticket in the KRBAPREQ is used to specify which secret key the server should use to decrypt that ticket.
segment.target: Because it is possible for the server to be registered in multiple realms, with different keys in each, the realm field in the unencrypted portion of the ticket in the KRBAPREQ is used to specify which secret key the server should use to decrypt that ticket.

segment.source: The KRBAPERRNOKEY error code is returned if the server doesn't have the proper key to decipher the ticket.
segment.target: The KRBAPERRNOKEY error code is returned if the server doesn't have the proper key to decipher the ticket.

segment.source: According RFC4120 this error message is obsolete.
segment.target: According RFC4120 this error message is obsolete.

segment.source: Inappropriate type of checksum in message (checksum may be unsupported)
segment.target: Inappropriate type of checksum in message (checksum may be unsupported)

segment.source: When KDC receives KRBTGSREQ message it decrypts it, and after that, the user-supplied checksum in the Authenticator MUST be verified against the contents of the request.
segment.target: When KDC receives KRBTGSREQ message it decrypts it, and after that, the user-supplied checksum in the Authenticator MUST be verified against the contents of the request.

segment.source: The message MUST be rejected either if the checksums do not match (with an error code of KRBAPERRMODIFIED) or if the checksum is not collision-proof (with an error code of KRBAPERRINAPPCKSUM).
segment.target: The message MUST be rejected either if the checksums do not match (with an error code of KRBAPERRMODIFIED) or if the checksum is not collision-proof (with an error code of KRBAPERRINAPPCKSUM).

segment.source: The size of a ticket is too large to be transmitted reliably via UDP.
segment.target: The size of a ticket is too large to be transmitted reliably via UDP.

segment.source: In a Windows environment, this message is purely informational.
segment.target: In a Windows environment, this message is purely informational.

segment.source: A computer running a Windows operating system will automatically try TCP if UDP fails.
segment.target: A computer running a Windows operating system will automatically try TCP if UDP fails.

segment.source: Group membership has overloaded the PAC.
segment.target: Group membership has overloaded the PAC.

segment.source: Multiple recent password changes have not propagated.
segment.target: Multiple recent password changes have not propagated.

segment.source: Crypto subsystem error caused by running out of memory.
segment.target: Crypto subsystem error caused by running out of memory.

segment.source: Field is too long for this implementation
segment.target: Field is too long for this implementation

segment.source: Each request (KRBKDCREQ) and response (KRBKDCREP or KRBERROR) sent over the TCP stream is preceded by the length of the request as 4 octets in network byte order.
segment.target: Each request (KRBKDCREQ) and response (KRBKDCREP or KRBERROR) sent over the TCP stream is preceded by the length of the request as 4 octets in network byte order.

segment.source: The high bit of the length is reserved for future expansion and MUST currently be set to zero.
segment.target: The high bit of the length is reserved for future expansion and MUST currently be set to zero.

segment.source: If a KDC that does not understand how to interpret a set high bit of the length encoding receives a request with the high order bit of the length set, it MUST return a KRB-ERROR message with the error KRBERRFIELDTOOLONG and MUST close the TCP stream.
segment.target: If a KDC that does not understand how to interpret a set high bit of the length encoding receives a request with the high order bit of the length set, it MUST return a KRB-ERROR message with the error KRBERRFIELDTOOLONG and MUST close the TCP stream.

segment.source: The client trust failed or is not implemented
segment.target: The client trust failed or is not implemented

segment.source: This typically happens when user’s smart-card certificate is revoked or the root Certification Authority that issued the smart card certificate (in a chain) is not trusted by the domain controller.
segment.target: This typically happens when user’s smart-card certificate is revoked or the root Certification Authority that issued the smart card certificate (in a chain) is not trusted by the domain controller.

segment.source: The KDC server trust failed or could not be verified
segment.target: The KDC server trust failed or could not be verified

segment.source: The trustedCertifiers field contains a list of certification authorities trusted by the client, in the case that the client does not possess the KDC's public key certificate.
segment.target: The trustedCertifiers field contains a list of certification authorities trusted by the client, in the case that the client does not possess the KDC's public key certificate.

segment.source: If the KDC has no certificate signed by any of the trustedCertifiers, then it returns an error of type KDCERRKDCNOTTRUSTED.
segment.target: If the KDC has no certificate signed by any of the trustedCertifiers, then it returns an error of type KDCERRKDCNOTTRUSTED.

segment.source: This error is related to PKINIT.
segment.target: This error is related to PKINIT.

segment.source: If a PKI trust relationship exists, the KDC then verifies the client's signature on AuthPack (TGT request signature).
segment.target: If a PKI trust relationship exists, the KDC then verifies the client's signature on AuthPack (TGT request signature).

segment.source: If that fails, the KDC returns an error message of type KDCERRINVALIDSIG.
segment.target: If that fails, the KDC returns an error message of type KDCERRINVALIDSIG.

segment.source: A higher encryption level is needed
segment.target: A higher encryption level is needed

segment.source: If the clientPublicValue field is filled in, indicating that the client wishes to use Diffie-Hellman key agreement, then the KDC checks to see that the parameters satisfy its policy.
segment.target: If the clientPublicValue field is filled in, indicating that the client wishes to use Diffie-Hellman key agreement, then the KDC checks to see that the parameters satisfy its policy.

segment.source: If they do not (e.g., the prime size is insufficient for the expected encryption type), then the KDC sends back an error message of type KDCERRKEYTOOWEAK.
segment.target: If they do not (e.g., the prime size is insufficient for the expected encryption type), then the KDC sends back an error message of type KDCERRKEYTOOWEAK.

segment.source: In the case that the client application doesn't know that a service requires user-to-user authentication, and requests and receives a conventional KRBAPREP, the client will send the KRBAPREP request, and the server will respond with a KRBERROR token as described in RFC1964, with a msg-type of KRBAPERRUSERTOUSERREQUIRED.
segment.target: In the case that the client application doesn't know that a service requires user-to-user authentication, and requests and receives a conventional KRBAPREP, the client will send the KRBAPREP request, and the server will respond with a KRBERROR token as described in RFC1964, with a msg-type of KRBAPERRUSERTOUSERREQUIRED.

segment.source: No TGT was presented or available
segment.target: No TGT was presented or available

segment.source: In user-to-user authentication if the service does not possess a ticket granting ticket, it should return the error KRBAPERRNOTGT.
segment.target: In user-to-user authentication if the service does not possess a ticket granting ticket, it should return the error KRBAPERRNOTGT.

segment.source: Although this error rarely occurs, it occurs when a client presents a cross-realm TGT to a realm other than the one specified in the TGT.
segment.target: Although this error rarely occurs, it occurs when a client presents a cross-realm TGT to a realm other than the one specified in the TGT.

segment.source: Typically, this results from incorrectly configured DNS.
segment.target: Typically, this results from incorrectly configured DNS.

segment.source: Ticket Encryption Type Type = HexInt32: the cryptographic suite that was used for issued TGT.
segment.target: Ticket Encryption Type Type = HexInt32: the cryptographic suite that was used for issued TGT.

segment.source: Disabled by default starting from Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2.
segment.target: Disabled by default starting from Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2.

segment.source: Disabled by default starting from Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2.
segment.target: Disabled by default starting from Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2.

segment.source: Supported starting from Windows Server 2008 and Windows Vista.
segment.target: Supported starting from Windows Server 2008 and Windows Vista.

segment.source: Supported starting from Windows Server 2008 and Windows Vista.
segment.target: Supported starting from Windows Server 2008 and Windows Vista.

segment.source: Default suite for operating systems before Windows Server 2008 and Windows Vista.
segment.target: Default suite for operating systems before Windows Server 2008 and Windows Vista.

segment.source: Default suite for operating systems before Windows Server 2008 and Windows Vista.
segment.target: Default suite for operating systems before Windows Server 2008 and Windows Vista.

segment.source: This type shows in Audit Failure events.
segment.target: This type shows in Audit Failure events.

segment.source: Pre-Authentication Type Type = UnicodeString: the code number of pre-Authentication type which was used in TGT request.
segment.target: Pre-Authentication Type Type = UnicodeString: the code number of pre-Authentication type which was used in TGT request.

segment.source: This is a normal type for standard password authentication.
segment.target: This is a normal type for standard password authentication.

segment.source: The ETYPE-INFO pre-authentication type is sent by the KDC in a KRB-ERROR indicating a requirement for additional pre-authentication.
segment.target: The ETYPE-INFO pre-authentication type is sent by the KDC in a KRB-ERROR indicating a requirement for additional pre-authentication.

segment.source: It is usually used to notify a client of which key to use for the encryption of an encrypted timestamp for the purposes of sending a PA-ENC-TIMESTAMP pre-authentication value.
segment.target: It is usually used to notify a client of which key to use for the encryption of an encrypted timestamp for the purposes of sending a PA-ENC-TIMESTAMP pre-authentication value.

segment.source: Never saw this Pre-Authentication Type in Microsoft Active Directory environment.
segment.target: Never saw this Pre-Authentication Type in Microsoft Active Directory environment.

segment.source: Used for Smart Card logon authentication.
segment.target: Used for Smart Card logon authentication.

segment.source: This type should also be used for Smart Card authentication, but in certain Active Directory environments, it is never seen.
segment.target: This type should also be used for Smart Card authentication, but in certain Active Directory environments, it is never seen.

segment.source: The ETYPE-INFO2 pre-authentication type is sent by the KDC in a KRB-ERROR indicating a requirement for additional pre-authentication.
segment.target: The ETYPE-INFO2 pre-authentication type is sent by the KDC in a KRB-ERROR indicating a requirement for additional pre-authentication.

segment.source: It is usually used to notify a client of which key to use for the encryption of an encrypted timestamp for the purposes of sending a PA-ENC-TIMESTAMP pre-authentication value.
segment.target: It is usually used to notify a client of which key to use for the encryption of an encrypted timestamp for the purposes of sending a PA-ENC-TIMESTAMP pre-authentication value.

segment.source: Never saw this Pre-Authentication Type in Microsoft Active Directory environment.
segment.target: Never saw this Pre-Authentication Type in Microsoft Active Directory environment.

segment.source: Supported starting from Windows Server 2012 domain controllers and Windows 8 clients.
segment.target: Supported starting from Windows Server 2012 domain controllers and Windows 8 clients.

segment.source: This type shows in Audit Failure events.
segment.target: This type shows in Audit Failure events.

segment.source: Certificate Issuer Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the Certification Authority that issued the smart card certificate.
segment.target: Certificate Issuer Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the Certification Authority that issued the smart card certificate.

segment.source: Populated in Issued by field in certificate.
segment.target: Populated in Issued by field in certificate.

segment.source: Certificate Serial Number Type = UnicodeString: smart card certificate’s serial number.
segment.target: Certificate Serial Number Type = UnicodeString: smart card certificate’s serial number.

segment.source: Can be found in Serial number field in the certificate.
segment.target: Can be found in Serial number field in the certificate.

segment.source: Certificate Thumbprint Type = UnicodeString: smart card certificate’s thumbprint.
segment.target: Certificate Thumbprint Type = UnicodeString: smart card certificate’s thumbprint.

segment.source: Can be found in Thumbprint field in the certificate.
segment.target: Can be found in Thumbprint field in the certificate.

segment.source: For 4768(S, F): A Kerberos authentication ticket (TGT) was requested.
segment.target: For 4768(S, F): A Kerberos authentication ticket (TGT) was requested.

segment.source: High-value accounts: You might have high-value domain or local accounts for which you need to monitor each action.
segment.target: High-value accounts: You might have high-value domain or local accounts for which you need to monitor each action.

segment.source: Examples of high-value accounts are database administrators, built-in local administrator account, domain administrators, service accounts, domain controller accounts and so on.
segment.target: Examples of high-value accounts are database administrators, built-in local administrator account, domain administrators, service accounts, domain controller accounts and so on.

segment.source: Monitor this event with the “User ID” that corresponds to the high-value account or accounts.
segment.target: Monitor this event with the “User ID” that corresponds to the high-value account or accounts.

segment.source: Anomalies or malicious actions: You might have specific requirements for detecting anomalies or monitoring potential malicious actions.
segment.target: Anomalies or malicious actions: You might have specific requirements for detecting anomalies or monitoring potential malicious actions.

segment.source: For example, you might need to monitor for use of an account outside of working hours.
segment.target: For example, you might need to monitor for use of an account outside of working hours.

segment.source: When you monitor for anomalies or malicious actions, use the “User ID” (with other information) to monitor how or when a particular account is being used.
segment.target: When you monitor for anomalies or malicious actions, use the “User ID” (with other information) to monitor how or when a particular account is being used.

segment.source: Non-active accounts: You might have non-active, disabled, or guest accounts, or other accounts that should never be used.
segment.target: Non-active accounts: You might have non-active, disabled, or guest accounts, or other accounts that should never be used.

segment.source: Monitor this event with the “User ID” that corresponds to the accounts that should never be used.
segment.target: Monitor this event with the “User ID” that corresponds to the accounts that should never be used.

segment.source: Account whitelist: You might have a specific whitelist of accounts that are the only ones allowed to perform actions corresponding to particular events.
segment.target: Account whitelist: You might have a specific whitelist of accounts that are the only ones allowed to perform actions corresponding to particular events.

segment.source: If this event corresponds to a “whitelist-only” action, review the “User ID” for accounts that are outside the whitelist.
segment.target: If this event corresponds to a “whitelist-only” action, review the “User ID” for accounts that are outside the whitelist.

segment.source: External accounts: You might be monitoring accounts from another domain, or “external” accounts that are not allowed to perform certain actions (represented by certain specific events).
segment.target: External accounts: You might be monitoring accounts from another domain, or “external” accounts that are not allowed to perform certain actions (represented by certain specific events).

segment.source: Monitor this event for the “Supplied Realm Name” corresponding to another domain or “external” location.
segment.target: Monitor this event for the “Supplied Realm Name” corresponding to another domain or “external” location.

segment.source: Account naming conventions: Your organization might have specific naming conventions for account names.
segment.target: Account naming conventions: Your organization might have specific naming conventions for account names.

segment.source: Monitor “User ID” for names that don’t comply with naming conventions.
segment.target: Monitor “User ID” for names that don’t comply with naming conventions.

segment.source: You can track all 4768 events where the Client Address is not from your internal IP range or not from private IP ranges.
segment.target: You can track all 4768 events where the Client Address is not from your internal IP range or not from private IP ranges.

segment.source: If you know that Account Name should be used only from known list of IP addresses, track all Client Address values for this Account Name in 4768 events.
segment.target: If you know that Account Name should be used only from known list of IP addresses, track all Client Address values for this Account Name in 4768 events.

segment.source: If Client Address is not from the whitelist, generate the alert.
segment.target: If Client Address is not from the whitelist, generate the alert.

segment.source: All Client Address = ::1 means local authentication.
segment.target: All Client Address = ::1 means local authentication.

segment.source: If you know the list of accounts which should log on to the domain controllers, then you need to monitor for all possible violations, where Client Address = ::1 and Account Name is not allowed to log on to any domain controller.
segment.target: If you know the list of accounts which should log on to the domain controllers, then you need to monitor for all possible violations, where Client Address = ::1 and Account Name is not allowed to log on to any domain controller.

segment.source: All 4768 events with Client Port field value 0 and 1024 should be examined, because a well-known port was used for outbound connection.
segment.target: All 4768 events with Client Port field value 0 and 1024 should be examined, because a well-known port was used for outbound connection.

segment.source: Also consider monitoring the fields shown in the following table, to discover the issues listed:
segment.target: Also consider monitoring the fields shown in the following table, to discover the issues listed:

segment.source: Certification authority name is not from your PKI infrastructure.
segment.target: Certification authority name is not from your PKI infrastructure.

segment.source: Certification authority name is not authorized to issue smart card authentication certificates.
segment.target: Certification authority name is not authorized to issue smart card authentication certificates.

segment.source: Value is 0, which means that pre-authentication was not used.
segment.target: Value is 0, which means that pre-authentication was not used.

segment.source: All accounts should use Pre-Authentication, except accounts configured with “Do not require Kerberos preauthentication,” which is a security risk.
segment.target: All accounts should use Pre-Authentication, except accounts configured with “Do not require Kerberos preauthentication,” which is a security risk.

segment.source: For more information, see Table 5. Kerberos Pre-Authentication types.
segment.target: For more information, see Table 5. Kerberos Pre-Authentication types.

segment.source: Value is not 15 when account must use a smart card for authentication.
segment.target: Value is not 15 when account must use a smart card for authentication.

segment.source: For more information, see Table 5. Kerberos Pre-Authentication types.
segment.target: For more information, see Table 5. Kerberos Pre-Authentication types.

segment.source: Value is not 2 when only standard password authentication is in use in the organization.
segment.target: Value is not 2 when only standard password authentication is in use in the organization.

segment.source: For more information, see Table 5. Kerberos Pre-Authentication types.
segment.target: For more information, see Table 5. Kerberos Pre-Authentication types.

segment.source: Value is not 138 when Kerberos Armoring is enabled for all Kerberos communications in the organization.
segment.target: Value is not 138 when Kerberos Armoring is enabled for all Kerberos communications in the organization.

segment.source: For more information, see Table 5. Kerberos Pre-Authentication types.
segment.target: For more information, see Table 5. Kerberos Pre-Authentication types.

segment.source: Value is 0x1 or 0x3, which means the DES algorithm was used.
segment.target: Value is 0x1 or 0x3, which means the DES algorithm was used.

segment.source: DES should not be in use, because of low security and known vulnerabilities.
segment.target: DES should not be in use, because of low security and known vulnerabilities.

segment.source: It is disabled by default starting from Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2.
segment.target: It is disabled by default starting from Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2.

segment.source: For more information, see Table 4. Kerberos encryption types.
segment.target: For more information, see Table 4. Kerberos encryption types.

segment.source: Starting with Windows Vista and Windows Server 2008, monitor for values other than 0x11 and 0x12.
segment.target: Starting with Windows Vista and Windows Server 2008, monitor for values other than 0x11 and 0x12.

segment.source: These are the expected values, starting with these operating systems, and represent AES-family algorithms.
segment.target: These are the expected values, starting with these operating systems, and represent AES-family algorithms.

segment.source: For more information, see Table 4. Kerberos encryption types.
segment.target: For more information, see Table 4. Kerberos encryption types.

segment.source: 0x6 (The username doesn't exist), if you see, for example N events in last N minutes.
segment.target: 0x6 (The username doesn't exist), if you see, for example N events in last N minutes.

segment.source: This can be an indicator of account enumeration attack, especially for highly critical accounts.
segment.target: This can be an indicator of account enumeration attack, especially for highly critical accounts.

segment.source: This error can occur if the domain controller cannot find the server's name in Active Directory.
segment.target: This error can occur if the domain controller cannot find the server's name in Active Directory.

segment.source: This will help you to find duplicate SPNs faster.
segment.target: This will help you to find duplicate SPNs faster.

segment.source: 0x9 (The client or server has a null key (master key)).
segment.target: 0x9 (The client or server has a null key (master key)).

segment.source: This error can help you to identify problems with Kerberos authentication faster.
segment.target: This error can help you to identify problems with Kerberos authentication faster.

segment.source: Microsoft systems should not request postdated tickets.
segment.target: Microsoft systems should not request postdated tickets.

segment.source: These events could help identify anomaly activity.
segment.target: These events could help identify anomaly activity.

segment.source: 0xC (Requested start time is later than end time), if you see, for example N events in last N minutes.
segment.target: 0xC (Requested start time is later than end time), if you see, for example N events in last N minutes.

segment.source: This can be an indicator of an account compromise attempt, especially for highly critical accounts.
segment.target: This can be an indicator of an account compromise attempt, especially for highly critical accounts.

segment.source: 0xE (KDC has no support for encryption type).
segment.target: 0xE (KDC has no support for encryption type).

segment.source: In general, this error occurs when the KDC or a client receives a packet that it cannot decrypt.
segment.target: In general, this error occurs when the KDC or a client receives a packet that it cannot decrypt.

segment.source: Monitor for these events because this should not happen in a standard Active Directory environment.
segment.target: Monitor for these events because this should not happen in a standard Active Directory environment.

segment.source: 0xF (KDC has no support for checksum type).
segment.target: 0xF (KDC has no support for checksum type).

segment.source: Monitor for these events because this should not happen in a standard Active Directory environment.
segment.target: Monitor for these events because this should not happen in a standard Active Directory environment.

segment.source: 0x12 (Client's credentials have been revoked), if you see, for example N events in last N minutes.
segment.target: 0x12 (Client's credentials have been revoked), if you see, for example N events in last N minutes.

segment.source: This can be an indicator of anomaly activity or brute-force attack, especially for highly critical accounts.
segment.target: This can be an indicator of anomaly activity or brute-force attack, especially for highly critical accounts.

segment.source: The authenticator was encrypted with something other than the session key.
segment.target: The authenticator was encrypted with something other than the session key.

segment.source: The result is that the KDC cannot decrypt the TGT.
segment.target: The result is that the KDC cannot decrypt the TGT.

segment.source: The modification of the message could be the result of an attack or it could be because of network noise.
segment.target: The modification of the message could be the result of an attack or it could be because of network noise.

segment.source: This error indicates that a specific authenticator showed up twice—the KDC has detected that this session ticket duplicates one that it has already received.
segment.target: This error indicates that a specific authenticator showed up twice—the KDC has detected that this session ticket duplicates one that it has already received.

segment.source: It could be a sign of attack attempt.
segment.target: It could be a sign of attack attempt.

segment.source: 0x29 (Message stream modified and checksum didn't match).
segment.target: 0x29 (Message stream modified and checksum didn't match).

segment.source: The authentication data was encrypted with the wrong key for the intended server.
segment.target: The authentication data was encrypted with the wrong key for the intended server.

segment.source: The authentication data was modified in transit by a hardware or software error, or by an attacker.
segment.target: The authentication data was modified in transit by a hardware or software error, or by an attacker.

segment.source: Monitor for these events because this should not happen in a standard Active Directory environment.
segment.target: Monitor for these events because this should not happen in a standard Active Directory environment.

segment.source: This error can help you more quickly identify problems with Kerberos authentication.
segment.target: This error can help you more quickly identify problems with Kerberos authentication.

segment.source: 0x3E (The client trust failed or is not implemented).
segment.target: 0x3E (The client trust failed or is not implemented).

segment.source: This error helps you identify logon attempts with revoked certificates and the situations when the root Certification Authority that issued the smart card certificate (through a chain) is not trusted by a domain controller.
segment.target: This error helps you identify logon attempts with revoked certificates and the situations when the root Certification Authority that issued the smart card certificate (through a chain) is not trusted by a domain controller.

segment.source: These errors can help you more quickly identify smart-card related problems with Kerberos authentication.
segment.target: These errors can help you more quickly identify smart-card related problems with Kerberos authentication.
